name: Moderna
title: 100% AI Proficiency with AI Academy

classification.classificationRationale: Validated Model 6a. Moderna's approach treats the ENTIRE organization as the AI unit — 100% adoption goal within 6 months, 80%+ mChat usage, 750+ custom GPTs. No named AI lab; instead, the AI Academy evolved from education to innovation incubator. The 'Generative AI Champions' (top 100 power users) serve as distributed enablers, not a centralized team. Contextual orientation: every employee expected to achieve AI proficiency within their role.

description:
Moderna exemplifies the enterprise-wide adoption model where the 'lab' is the entire organization. The company set a goal of achieving 100% AI proficiency across all employees with access to digital solutions within six months, supported by a structured three-layer change management approach.

The three layers operate as: Individual (in-depth research, listening programs, trainings), Collective (AI prompt contest identified top 100 power users who became 'Generative AI Champions'), and Structural (AI Academy evolved from educational content to an innovation incubator for AI capability, projects, and ideas). mChat, Moderna's internal chatbot on OpenAI's API, achieved 80%+ employee adoption. Since deploying ChatGPT Enterprise, the company has generated 750+ custom GPTs.

After reporting a $1B quarterly loss in 2025, Moderna restructured to treat AI as a collaborator rather than a tool, creating a new role of Chief People and Digital Technology Officer overseeing merged HR and tech departments. This enables 'work planning' instead of 'workforce planning' — managing work outputs rather than headcount. The informational nature of mRNA technology provides natural AI-biology fit.

openQuestions: What specific AI applications are being used in mRNA drug design vs. corporate functions?
How does the merged HR/Tech department under Chief People and Digital Technology Officer work in practice?

taxonomyFeedback: Moderna's three-layer change management (Individual, Collective, Structural) is a well-articulated framework for enterprise-wide AI adoption that could inform taxonomy descriptions of Model 6a.
The mRNA-AI fit ('informational nature of mRNA lends itself to AI') suggests industry-specific habitat conditions that make certain models more natural.

[2026-02] Earnings call language is notably thin on AI structure — CEO mentions 'a large number of GPTs' but no details on how these are governed or coordinated. This supports classification as 6a (informal/contextual) rather than a more structured model. The Chief People and Digital Technology Officer role is interesting structurally — merging HR and Tech suggests Moderna is treating AI adoption as fundamentally a people/change management challenge, not a technology problem.
